title-group.article-title: Cargo Airlift What's Old? What's New?

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1987 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: World air cargo traffic will grow to nearly 120 billion revenue tonne-kilometers in the year 2000, 42 percent in freighters and 58 percent in passenger aircraft with lower deck or “arily through incorporation of ultra-high-bypass (UHB) propulsion. New concepts for containers and aircraft cargo/baggage handling systems arc proposed to meet the time-compressed demands placed by major hub/spoke operations. The new advanced MD-11 trijct passenger/combi/freighter is briefly reviewed, as are three advanced-design standard.body derivative freighter candidates for the 1990s: the MD-91X, MD-92X, and the all-new MD-94X, which may derive from a double-aisle passenger baseline. A candidate concept for the “Orient Express” is touched on.

Commercial Aircraft, 1986-2000 Outlook, Report No. CI-901-8327, Douglas Aircraft Company, August 1986.

H. F. Morrison, Jr., Cargo Handling Tray, Patent Dept. Docket No. R-7010, Douglas Aircraft Company, 19 June 1981.
The Orient Express, Report No. MDC-K0285, Douglas Aircraft Company, May 1986.
